reviewText: Cecil B. DeMille's remake of his 1923 film about the Exodus was a massive, but well-conducted undertaking.While its look is dated, its dialogue and acting sometimes fluctuating between overly dramatic and staid, and overly riddled with profundities, it's still enjoyable to watch for the color, spectacle and the special effects. Every frame of this film, could have appeared as an illustration on a page of the contemporary  picture Bibles.Summoning the viewers'attention is the equally bold and dramatic score by Elmer Bernstein. The the narration of a wise and grandfatherly De Mille leads us through the early part of the Book of Exodus as the international cast play their parts.Fearing the enslaved Hebrews, who out number them in their own country, Egypt's ruler, Rameses I (Ian Keith) orders the slaughter of their male infants.Hoping against hope for her own infant son's survival amid the horror, a Hebrew mother named Yochabel(Martha Scott) sets her infant son(Fraser Clarke Heston) adrift in a basket on the Nile in a desperate attempt to alter his fate, sending her young daughter, Miriam (Babette Bain)  to watch over him.A short distance away, the Pharaoh's daughter, Bithiah ( Nina Foch) and her attendants are bathing in the river outside the palace. As these giggling, pleasure-filled maidens give viewers  a brief edification about purported  foods and superstitions of Ancient Egyptians,the Princess discovers the infant in its little ark and sends them away, requesting only the assistance of her maid, Memnet(Judith Anderson) in rescuing the baby. One of many notable  moments of dramatic license occurs when Memnet identifies the child as a Hebrew by his swaddling cloth. But on pain of death, she is sworn to secrecy.Years pass.The now-grown Moses(Charlton Heston) returns in triumph after a military conquest. Awaiting him at the palace are the Pharaoh Sethi (Cedrick Hardwicke), his jealous biological son, Prince Rameses( a brooding and appropriately exotic Yul Brynner), and the Throne Princess, Nefertiri(Anne Baxter in her most actressy role), as well as Bithiah.With a charismatic boom in his voice, Moses arrives at court  with the spoils of victory and the promise of proctection by the Ethiopian King(Woody Strode) and his sister, Princess Thurbis(Esther Brown). His prestige grows as does his rivalry with Rameses.The plight of the slaves grows increasingly bitter. An added note of realism in their misery is the Hebrew overseer, Dathan( a trollish Edward G. Robinson), whose unscrupulous hustling makes him wealthy at the expense of his own people.A slightly heartening moment is seen in the  budding romance of a stone cutter named Joshua(John Derek) and the water girl, Lilia(Debra Paget, whose name, I suspect has no Biblical authenticity). In due time, we see how first Baka the Egyptian Master Builder( a characteristically smarmy Vincent Price)and then Dathan create despair for these lovers.Moses impresses Sethi by building  the city he ordered, and Sethi promises to make sure history remembers him.This will happen, but not for the reasons he thinks.Soon Moses deals with the matter of an old stone greaser, rescued from being trapped under a moving stone, and poignant chords resonate as unbeknownst to him, he is reunited with his biological mother.The wheels of events leading to Hebrew Emancipation are set in motion by an ill-fated confrontation between Memnet and Nefretiri. Bithiah makes one last vain attempt to hide the truth, but when Moses meets his biological family, including siblings Mirian and Aaron(Olive Deering and John Carradine), there is no turning back.Rage over a slave's mistreatment leads to Moses' downfall and exile, amid Rameses' gloating and Nefretiri's devastation.But Moses begins a new life in the desert as the husband of a shepherd girl named Sephora (Yvonne De Carlo) whose father is the Sheik of Midian(Eduard Franz). He raises his son, Gershom (Tommy Duran) and is reunited with Joshua.Seeing a strange light on the mountain compells Moses to inspect it and God (voiced by Donald Hayne) tells him His plans for Israel's Emancipation.Returning to Egypt, where Rameses is now Pharaoh, Moses and Aaron confront him at Court, where  God  demostrates His power through the two brothers.Miriam's role in advocating for her brother is noted as well.The most devastating of the 10 Plagues results in the Hebrew's gaining their freedom, and one feels as though they are actually witnessing the event.The first Passover finds Moses' nephew, Eleazar(Paul De Rolf) beginning the tradition of asking the Questions of Passover.Liberation Day is a day of Jubilee, after which one final unsucessful pursuit by the Egyptians comes hard and fast. Victorious in their  final bid for freedom, Israel awaits Moses return from atop Mount Sinai, and Dathan has one last chance for mischief before fire and brimstone set in.The film features many extras whose careers ascended in the following decade.  Kathy Garver("Family Affair") plays a little girl named Rachel, Robert Vaughn a spearman and a Hebrew before the Golden Calf, the first Mrs. Sammy Davis Jr., Loray White, is a Nubian slave girl, and musician Herb Alpert is featured as a Drummer on Mount Sinai.Ultimately, as Bithia and Sethi predicted, the name of the Great Law Giver will be remembered for all time, and the impact of the Commandments given to him by God will guide Mankind throughout eternity.

reviewText: Well -- what can one say?  I once wrote a review on this movie incollege, that lasted for pages and pages and pages.....and theteacher wrote that my review was almost as long as the movie!  ItWAS, and IS impressive....all those extras, all those incrediblesets, (and incredible costumes!), all that tribal loyalty, (Yoche-bed: "..But we cannot leave, we are Levites, appointed shepherdsof Israel...") all that hackneyed dialogue, ("...I will, greatprince!"  "You couldn't even kill him...", etc. etc.) all thosecorney situations, (Prince Moses saves an old slave-woman frombeing crushed to death....not realizing it's really his own birth-mother), etc.  The music, by Elmer Bernstein is stirring, (but onrepeated playings, corny as well) -- and one can't help wonder-ing how this movie played, not so much in Peoria, Illinois -- butin the strangely-named city of Goshen, New York....A rabbi who was a neighbour and friend, saw this movie, and hadtwo complaints about it.  One: first you saw Moses as a littlebaby -- and then you saw him as a young, but grown, man.  Themovie purports to show "the missing years of Moses' life". Well,maybe a few, after he reached the age of manhood -- but whatwas he like as a kid, and a teen-ager?  NONE of this was shown-- and it could have added so much to the movie, had it beenshown, (even if invented).  Like -- Moses showing equal treat-ment of men and women, Moses REFUSING to join the carousing ofother Egyptian noblemen, (especially Rameses!), for a night,(or two), of extra-sexual activity, drunkenness, etc. Mosestreating a brilliant, but handicapped young slave as an (almost-)equal, Moses learning at the best Egyptian Universities, (he issaid to have done this), Moses............well, you can fill inyour own ideas of how the humanism, rectitude, curiousity aboutthe universe, and all the other good-guy stuff you'd want togive to Prince Moses, (think: combination of George Clooney,J.F.K., Albert Schweitzer, Teddy Roosevelt, Prince Albert (ofEngland -- though Prince Albert of Monaco isn't a bad choiceeither), Bill Gates, (who, in a sense, has "freed" many peo-ple, who today can easily use, (and even, in many instances,monetarily profit from using), the computer, J.F.K. Jr., (whobelonged to the 'Robin Hood Society'), and your own favouritemale high-school teacher.  Etc., etc.  Moses is now seen,not just as a stern, (perhaps the sternest), Old Testamentprophet -- but as a charismatic, handsome, and compassionateyoung man....and we carry these ideas about Moses' characterinto the later part of the movie, for we have seen him in the"movie-matinee" mode in the earlier part of the movie. Sadly,the scenes of Moses' youth are very few here, almost non-existent, but what what IS shown, can easily be translatedinto ideas of one's own, concerning Moses' youth and teenyears, which I have tried to do here -- and to which, ofcourse, anyone can add.  (This film can be used as a realspringboard for Sunday-school discussion -- for any age!)Charlton Heston's "brauvora" performance, especiallyas Prince Moses, did much to add romanticism and glamourto this erstwhile stern Biblical character, as, a few yearslater, "Dark Shadows"' JONATHAN FRID added a romantic tingeto what was heretofore most un-romantic of characters, avampire!Still, these EARLY formative years of Moses were hardly shown in"The Ten Commandments", and neighbour and friend, the rabbi wholiterally DID live next-door, was disappointed.  I guess so wasI....but the performance of Mr. Heston DID make me think ofincidents, (some of which are mentioned above), that SHOULDhave been included.  (I also made up a play, "CAROL AND MOSES",about a 22nd century schoolgirl who falls down her own time-machine into the time of Moses, with humourous and educationalresults.  The play impressed my Hebrew-school teacher, and Ilater even used it as a college term-paper!  Sadly, however, itgot lost....)  Anyway, the second thing the rabbi-next-doorwas upset about was that Moses was often called, "The Deliverer"in 'The Ten Commandments'.  But the usual usage of the term,"The Deliverer", rightly belongs in the NEW Testament, (describ-ing Jesus), and NOT in the Old Testament.  Did Cecil B. DeMillefind a reference to Moses in the Old Testament that no one elsehas?  Or did he allow a New Testament phrase to migrate to theOld Testament, simply becaue he wanted to?  It's OK, I guess, totamper with HISTORY, for dramatic effect.  But titles of Honourshould, he felt, (and I also feel), stay with the personagesthey were given to.  (For the record, Moses is, in Jewishparlance, often referred to, NOT as "The Deliverer", but as"Moses, Our Teacher".)  Christians, too, I feel, should lookaskance at this, for, to Christians, it is Jesus who is theDeliverer -- not Moses, or anyone else!)For the record, too, it is NOT stated in the Bible, (at least asfar as I know), that Moses ever became a slave, voluntarily ornot.  The Bible merely says that Moses "looked into" the burdenshis people bore -- much as a kindly warden might look in at hisprisoners, to see that they were well fed, and that their cellswere as clean as possible, etc. But the warden would not go tolive in a cell himself!  In the traditional story, Moses DOESknow of his lineage since childhood.  He feels conscience-strick-en -- but knows that God has placed him in the palace so that hewould not have the bitter, angry "slave mentality" that oftenaccompanies being in the lower rungs of society -- so that hecould eventually become the leader the Hebrews needed.  Infact, in the introduction to the movie, (now restored andincluded in this 50th Anniversary Edition), Cecil B. DeMillesays, (and/or admits), that he did not think it was possiblefor Moses to have empathy for his people without experiencingtheir pain.  So, in this movie, (with, admittedly, no Biblicalback-up), Moses indeed becomes a slave.  However, I suspectthat it was more than just a belief, on Mr. DeMille's part, that  Moses was understand his people's pain without personally ex-periencing it.  Nope -- I definitely feel that this "little"status demotion was put in purely for heroic and dramatic effect.I mean, who amongst us would like to meet, say, a high-schoolfriend, (or worse, worse, foe), who has over the years becomean enormous financial success -- while we....  The universaltheme of embarrassment, (often attached to heroism and sexual-ity -- a recurring theme in many of Mr. DeMille's movies), isagain brought into play, here....  Princess Nefretiri, in allher finery, travelling through Goshen, seeing, (or is thatseeking out?), her former fiance, ("the real dirty one"),treading in the mud pits, is fraught with class-war, deepembarrassment, sexual tension, and probably a great deal more.None of this could have been shown, of course, had Cecil B. De-Mille followed The Book of Exodus exactly -- but I guess that'swhat licence", means.  At least Mr. Demille DOES admit tinker-ing with this part of the story in the newly-restored Intro-duction.  However, in the traditional version, of this story,Moses leaves Egypt ONLY because he has "killed an Egyptian",here, it is VINCENT PRICE, as Pharaoh's "master-builder" andarchitect).  But, in Mr. DeMille's version, he adds in the ad-ditional reason of Rameses seeking out "the Deliverer" -- andfinding him, (with the additional advantage of finding THEway to the throne, as Nefretari -- the Hereditary 'Throne-Princess",  cannot, obviously, now marry Moses.)  This allowsfor even more sexual tension in the movie -- but THIS tinkeringwith the story, (is Nefretari even mentioned in the Bible?) isNOT apologized for....Another interesting side-light is the fact that a minor characternamed "Hur Ben-Caleb" is shown and featured in the program book."Ben", meant, (and still means) "the son of", in Hebrew.  It isprobably possible, (as this character was important enough to bementioned in the program book -- and probably is mentioned in theBible as well), that "HUR Ben-Caleb" was chosen as the ancestorof the fictional "Judah Ben-HUR", by Lew Wallace!  (And played byCharlton Heston, of course, in the later film, "Ben Hur"!)  Afurther interesting sidelight is the fact that the actor whoportrayed Hur Ben Caleb was LAURENCE DOBKIN.  Mr. Dobkin, whoplayed many, (many, many!), roles, (and who died quite recently,in 2002), was, in my own mind, most memorable for a role that heplayed in 1957, (the year following the release of "The TenCommandments.  On "Letter To Loretta", (aka "The Loretta YoungShow"), he played Pharaoh Akenaton, in two episodes! (I supposethe producers of the "Loretta Young Show" thought he had "experi-ence" in parts relating to ancient Egypt!  All I know, is that,so many years later, I don't remember his performance in "TheLoretta Young Show"....but I DO remember that it was so good,that I DO remember his name!The scope of the film is enormous, the ambition to encompass all,(and more), unyielding.  You can tell everyone involved withthis movie was whole-heartedly "into" making it.  A man with thelast name of "Nurdlinger" or "Nordlinger" wrote a book on themaking of "The Ten Commandments", and it is stated in theprogram book for the initial release of the movie, in 1956, thatthis was the VERY first book to describe the making of any movie.(The program book is, as well, filled with astonishingly beautifulpaintings by artist ARNOLD FRIEBERG, instead of movie stills.These paintings are worthy of being framed -- but I was alwaysdisappointed that the "quick clip", showing only for a few frames,but dazzelingly memorable, of the "three daughters of Jeptha",their hair blowing in the wind, as Moses performed one of hismiracles, was not one of these paintings.)  Later on, the name"Nurdlinger"/or/"Nordlinger" showed up in the movie, "GoodNeighbour Sam", which starred JACK LEMON -- also starring EDWARDG. ROBINSON, (who appears in The Ten Commandments as 'Dathan') asthe modern-day businessman, named Nurdlinger/Nordlinger, (a nicetribute to the man who wrote the book on the making of "The TenCommandments"!)  It is also interesting to note that H.B. WARNER,who plays the bit -- but deeply memorable role, as 'the old manwho dried up in the dust', (his strength gives out just beforethe Hebrews leave Egypt), played Jesus Christ in Cecil B. Demille'soriginal "King of Kings".  (All information from the originalprogram book for 'The Ten Commandments'.)A great disappointment to me, upon viewing this movie, was thatthe famous "40 years wandering" of the Hebrews after they leftEgypt was barely touched on.  In one scene, you see Moses, Joshua,Lilia, and the other major players, JUST after they had leftEgypt.  The very next scene shows that they all have aged -- andthe Forty Years Wandering is hardly noticed at all.  Yet this"40 Years Wandering" has a very, very important message.  Peopleask, goodness -- why did they have to wander around for fortyyears, when they could have reached "the promised land" so muchmore quickly?  The answer I was given is this: God wanted allof those born into slavery, (most of whom had, because of exper-ience and necessity, acquired the exasperated, negative, and bitter, 'slave mentality'), to die -- so that only the free-born, (and presumably positive) newer generation would enter,and build, the new nation.  To me, this has always been a"count your blessings" message.  True, even in our modern world -- what with income taxes, nosy neighbours, sometimes-impossible bossesand co-workers, crowded buses, subways, and highways -- not tomention ever-increasing prices on seemingly just about everything,it's real easy to become very, very embittered, and exasperated and negative, indeed!  Yet -- despite it all, most people, (exceptfor the REAL slaves that, sadly, DO still exist in hidden areasof the world, and about whom a news story or two does still popup on occasion), are, today, accounted to be free -- and citizensof a country to boot!  Nasty office bosses may make life miserable-- but one can always quit, (unlike "Abby" -- as played by PAULETTEGODDARD -- in another memorable deMille movie, "Unconquered" -- who,as an 18th-century slave girl, delivers the memorable line, "Slavescan't quit."  (DeMille really did have "a thing" about slavery,as it turns up in several of his movies.  I suppose, to him, itconnotes FIGHTING slavery -- which is heroism, (which equalsbox-office draw, amongst other things.)  And, yep, crowded buses, subways, and rush-hour traffic aren't at all pleasant -- but allof them sure beat walking!  I guess what I'm trying to say hereis that having a bitter, "slave mentality" can come to anyone --even someone who is born, and considers themselves, to be free!Yet, I'm sure that SOME of those thousands of ancient Hebrews who  Egypt, survived the 40 years of wandering.  Because they hadin slavery, (and continued to have, in freedom), the positivemental attitude that, amongst other things, truly keeps a personyoung -- in heart, and in spirit -- and often, in appearance aswell.  (Smiling, by the way, uses less muscles and energy thanfrowning.)  It's NOT easy to have a positive mental attitude--I, too, often get depressed.  A lot.  But when I think of thereason why God is said to have caused the "forty years wandering",and the few people, (50? 100? 500?), out of the many thousands ofpeople who endured the 40 years wandering, that I'm just sure HADto survive it, (to become shining examples for others, as well as having happy lives for themselves), things in my own life -- asimperfect and unhappy as it sometimes is -- seems better thanit could be, even so.  It's not perfect -- so I'll try to improveit!  (Just yesterday, in fact, I found a good diet aid -- apple-cider vinegar PILLS and TABLETS! Apple-cider vinegar is supposedto be great for dieting...but oh, the taste! But now I finallydiscover it can be had in pill and tablet form!  And they arefor sale right here on Amazon, too!  Hooray!)  Winston Churchillwas asked, towards the end of his life, if he had any advicefor future generations.  His response?  "Yes.  I can give it inseven words.  Never give up!  Never, never give up!"  Yes, thatis also the Churchill family motto -- but I often wonder ifWinston Churchill, too, derived the same meaning from thinkingabout the famous "forty years wandering", (like I have), asas described in the Bible, (but not, sadly, truly explored inthe movie, "The Ten Commandments").  Still, something to thinkabout...But another interesting sidelight on this movie is this: the 1990sPBS series, "MythQuest" -- a series designed for intelligent teens, but which can be watched with equal interest by curious, questing (!) adults, which involved two teens seeking their father, who hadbecome entrapped by an evil god, into a sort of myth-seeker/time-machine, had an interesting echo of "The Ten Commandments" inits final episode.  A neigbour-lady, (in the present), namedBarbara, had been a busy-body and a bully in several of theprevious episodes.  Somehow, she steps into the beam of the myth-seeker/time-machine, just at the WRONG moment -- and in an instant,her high-heels and smart business suit have disappeared, and shesuddenly and totally unexpectedly, finds herself in Biblicalclothes, waist-deep in a Goshen treading pit!  Within twoseconds, she is whipped -- then, suddenly, finds herself backin the present...  (Or maybe she dosn't get back to the present-- it's been a while since I've seen the series...so I don'tactually remember.  But I guess the writers of that episodeof "Mythquest" were as impresed with "The Ten Commandments" asI was.....)All and all, I'd say, this is a "must-see" movie -- at leastonce.  No movie is perfect, and I'm sure many younger people,seeing this movie for the first time, will laugh, (and pehaps,squirm), at some of the dialogue and actions.  I've seen itwritten, ("so let it be written -- so let it be done!") that Mr.de Mille always went for the 'lowest common denominator' -- andthat is surely the truth in this movie.  Heroism and sex, sexand heroism...impressive costuming and sets, stirring music --these things ALWAYS sell, and Mr. DeMille knew it. Corny dialogueobviously didn't matter to Mr. DeMille -- and it is a pity, becauseotherwise, this movie should get ten stars, with it's impressivesets, costumes, and the fact that it keeps the Passover story, and  all the ramifications of freedom, responsibility, and slavery,continually in people's minds.  Yet, some it still has some scenesthat are not, (in my mind, anyway), the least bit corny -- likethose where Moses meets, (and saves) Jethro's daughters, and hiscourtship of the eldest, Sephora, (YVONNE DE CARLO) -- who, (withfeminity AND with feminism -- (in 1956!), fought the invadingshepherds as well, are quiet movie milestones.  Moses and Sephora,speaking of, and gazing at, the far-off Mount Sinai, while theyspeak of Egypt, freedom, and each other, is unforgettablyelegant and memorable.  One wishes that the rest of the moviewas as "corn-free" as this simple scene, and a few of those that directly preceeded it, was....It also must be noted that the acting in this movie is superb --especialy by the major characters.  No -- they do not completelyovercome the so-often cloying, unsettling, and extremely cornydialogue, but they come as close to overcoming it as humanlypossible!  So good was the acting here -- especially by CharltonHeston and Yul Brynner -- that it came as a positive shock to me,years and years later, to learn that it was Mr. Heston who was,in real life, politcally conservative, whilst Mr. Brynner, in reallife, was a liberal!  (But both of them, obviously, cared verymuch for the cause of Human Freedom -- only they had differentpaths to the same goal.  Mr. Heston's speeches, many years afterthe release of "The Ten Commandments", in favour of gun ownership for individual American citizens, are very well known. Perhaps less well known are the very, very powerful anti-smoking ads which Mr. Brynner made, towards the very, very end of his life, as he was dying fromlung cancer.  These, too, are classics!_____(( ))_____((  ))_____((  ))____((  ))_____((  ))_____.AN IMPORTANT EPILOGUE:  When I think of the movie, "The TenCommandments", and the Passover story which it tries sovaliantly to tell, I also begin to think about somethingquite important -- espeically for today -- that I learnt inHebrew school.  And that was this.  THE JEWS DID N O T BECOMESLAVES IN EGYPT ALL AT ONCE!  No -- at first, (when, say, thegreat-great-grand-children of the 12 brothers of Jacob whocame to Egypt during the famine in Israel), began to multiplylike rabbits, the Egyptians said to them: "Since you arestrangers here, you have to put in a few hours each weekbuilding Pharaoh's treasure cities."  So, for a few hourseach week, they did....  Later on, this was increased to afew days a week.... then two weeks out of the month....andthen finally, the Egypians said to the Hebrews, "Look --you're spending SO much time in Goshen...why don't you justgo live there?"  THAT'S when they became slaves, in name and'in toto'.THOMAS JEFFERSON said that 'Eternal Vigilance is the Price ofLiberty.'  Considering the alternative, it really isn't ahigh price to pay -- but it IS difficult.  My advice?  Watchto see that, (in the words of WILL ROGERS), 'our hired helpin Washington', doesn't get TOO power-hungry over the rest ofus, (their fellow-citizens!)  Remember too, one of theslogans of the American Revolution: ("Don't Tread On Me").The treading pits of Egypt -- and of "The Ten Commandments"-- were bad enough.  I, of course, being a Libertarian, feelthis is the only way out -- but those belonging to otherparties should also keep a sharp watch on their "representa-tives" and "party leaders".  Remember the saying, "thosewho forget the past are condemned to relive it."  With 'secretsocieties' all around, I, truly, am alarmed.  (In fact, some conspiracy theorists say that the chief members of these secret societies have always been recruited, from the same thirteenfamilies -- SINCE THE TIME OF ANCIENT EGYPT!)  But there isanother saying, "Forwarned is fore-armed."  We may not haveMoses around any more -- but we DO have the innate goodnessthat is at the core of all human beings, and all modernreligions.  Bank on that, and, like the Hebrews in the movie,"The Teh Commandments", you will see a "promised land", anda "light at the end of the tunnel."For me, this means being a proud Libertarian, for -- althoughI have never, thank goodness, formally been enslaved, I havemet many authority figures whom I do not trust. From a ratheraustere first and second grade teacher, who NEVER should havetaught children that young, to a doctor who had an ego whichwas SO big that other doctors now still talk of it -- eventhough he died over 20 years ago, and other neighbours andpeople I have met in passing that still people my nightmares.As well, I do not like the idea of senators and congress-peoplehaving health-insurance and pension plans far more favourablerest of us are ever likely to see.  "Power corrupts, and abso-lute power corrupts absolutely," so the saying goes.  WillRogers said that he wanted to "go down to Washington and seehow our hired help are getting along" -- but all too often,self-important, elected law-makers, (in all countries), don'tseem to remember that they are ONLY "hired help", and nothingmore.  Libertarian Dr. Ron Paul wants to A B O L I S H theIRS, (amongst other good things), and Libertarian Senator MikeGravel wants to run frequent plebecites, (referendums), sothat the voices of individual citizens may more often be heard.THESE are "my guys"!  In them, I see the TRUE light of freedom,as freedom should be.  I realize, of course, that others havetheir own, different favourite political parties and paths toFreedom -- but as the Libertarian Party, and it's leadingpoliticians, are so grievoulsy given so very little publicityin the press and news media, I hope I may be forgiven forgiving them just a little bit of publicity here -- because,after all, one subject herein discussed, is, of course,Freedom itself!Sorry if THIS review, too, might be as long, (or longer?) thanthe movie, but there are, I feel, important things in thisreview that HAVE to be said!

reviewText: I got this because of the contrast it would make with the Dreamworks cartoon version, which my kids love.  In particular, I remembered the tension between Ramses and Moses as potentially murderous rivals for the throne, which is almost entirely absent from the Spielberg version.  Brenner is absolutely brilliant as the ruthless Ramses, who wants Nefretiri for the power, not for love.  (We regard these stories as living myths in our home, to be enjoyed but also to be compared and discussed.)  From the start, the kids were far less interested than I was, a sure sign that the film is dated - me preferring almost dinosaurian versions, they the slick new ones with flawless effects and more modern scripts.What struck me right off was the stilted dialogue, so over-the-top melodramatic, and the stylized acting, not at all in the method-acting tradition but rather a caricature of the flourishes from the silent screen.  (Moses, for example, saves his mother by chance, who later cannot deny that he is her son, even at the cost of his position.)  Oddly, I did not remember it that way, though the last time I saw this was in the mid-80s - I didn't watch it every Easter.  This stylistic aspect really put my kids off, whereas I enjoyed it as a kind of relic from the films of my childhood.Nonetheless, the narrative did carry us all along and we enjoyed discussing the Egyptian empire, the way that slaves and Jews were treated, and the character of Moses as a leader of his people.  It is a great story, a timeless classic, and there is no question that this film taps into that, however dated it appears.  The setting and sets are also wonderful, evoking the wonder of human history. reviewText: Not having seen "The Ten Commandments" for many, many years the first thing that struck me was that this film is a bona fide Cold War artifact! DeMille's courtain raiser leaves no doubt of the propaganda intent.... this is no mere biblical tale but an epic of the "struggle for freedom" at a time when "freedom" is threatened once again all over the world (read the Red Menace). Throughout the ponderous script the struggle is for "freedom" not for Hebrews (I don't think the word Jew is ever uttered) to become a nation and seek a homeland. Never has De Mille been closer to a carnival barker as he touts his "sources" and makes his pitch for momentous contemporary relevance.  This alone is worth the price of admission, well, rental.Unfortunately, then there is the movie.  The script is ridiculous, riddled with lines which are more evocative of Maria Montez's "I have spoken..." in "Cobra Woman" than whatever version of Exodus one wishes to quote. And it goes on and on and on and on. Some scenes are indeed grand, such as the exit from Egypt, but others seem mired in stolid silent film composition: one expects Francis X. Bushman to strut in any minute.  Charleton Heston, Sir Cedric Hardwicke, Nina Foch and Yvonne de Carlo carry themselves with some dignity; Anne Baxter, Yul Brynner, Vincent Price and most others are just shy of scenery chewing. I found Edgar G. Robinson the most palatable of the lot in a rather nasty role. Make-up and costumes are somewhat cheesy, with Charleton Heston's becoming increasingly funnier as he gets older.... by the end he looks no better than he would if this were a cash-strapped pageant at your local bible school. The attempts to make him look like Michelangelo's Moses are hilarious.The Anniversary Edition transfer is marvelous.  The colors leap at you like they probably never did in a theatre. The special effects are primitive.  Whatever camp/fun value one may find is quickly dissipated by the plodding pace and extraordinary length of a tale we know already, which has value only in how it is retold. In this case, it's De Mille's solemnly tedious telling which  does it in.Packaged with the sound film is the silent version De Mille made much earlier in his career. Well, that one was no great shakes either. However, I am looking forward to the reissue of delicious De Mille behemoths promised for later this month (May 2006), particularly Claudette Colbert's milk bath in "Sign of the Cross" and the grandest barge ever where Claudette reigns as "Cleopatra" (a much better film than the Taylor/Burton dud).Of course, the historicity of Moses (or a Moses-like figure) and the Pentateuch is a matter quite separate from this film.  Only the very gullible would take lovable carnival barker De Mille at his word.

It figures you know all that so it goes right ahead to the persecutions of the Hebrews in building the pyramids and Moses warning Pharoah about the plagues. After the obligatory Golden calf scene, the film skips ahead to a (VERY) thinly related 1923 morality play about two brothers, one a pious devotee to Biblical teachings and the other a soulles cad and mocker of religion. reviewText: Cecil B. DeMille's last film, his 1956 biblical epic "The Ten Commandments", is old school Hollywood at his best. The old adage "They don't make 'em like they used to anymore" applies very well to this film. In this day in which Hollywood favors PC values over true storytelling, a film like "The Ten Commandments" could not be made without a heap of politically correct mandates that would seriosuly alter the story which, whether true or not (I personally believe it, even if I do think certain moments are exagerrated), is one of the most powerful and inspiring tales ever told."The Ten Commandments", of course, tells the story of Moses (played by the legendary Charlton Heston in one of cinema's greatest performances), the son of Hebrew slaves who is found floating in the bushes by the Egyptian queen Bithia (Nina Foch). Raised by Bithia and Sethi (Sir Cedrick Hardwicke), the rulers of Egypt.Years pass by, and Moses is now competing with his brother Ramses (Yul Brynner, whose performance is just as outstanding as Heston's) for the throne of Egypt as well as for the heart of the beautiful Nefretiri (Anne Baxter), who already has her heart set on Moses.One thing that Moses and Ramses greatly differ on is the treatment of the Hebrew slaves. Ramses is for the brutal treatment brought upon them by the sadistic slave-driver Baka (a brief but memorable turn by Vincent Price), as well as the tamer acts of the chief Hebrew overseer Dathan (the great Edward G. Robinson). Moses, on the other hand, cares for their safety, giving them food and even granting 1 day in 7 of rest, and developing a close bond with the stone cutter Joshua (John Derek), who is in love with the flower girl Lilia (Debra Paget) and also believes that Moses is God's messenger. This sets off a bitter conflict between him and his brother, one that tensely escalates throughout the course of the movie.When the royal nurse Memnet (Judith Anderson) reveals to Nefretiri that Moses is not of true Egyptian descent and is in fact the child of Hebrew slaves, this results in Moses looking for his true roots. He finds out that his mother is Hebrew slave named Yochabel (Martha Scott, who later went on to play Heston's mother in another classic biblical epic, "Ben-Hur"). Angered, Ramses casts out Moses from the kingdom to Mithian. There, Moses meets and falls in love with the beautiful Sephora (the recently deceased Yvonne De Carlo, famous for playing Lilly Munster), whom he marries and his a son with. He also, in an effort to find out whether or not the God he is said to be a messenger of truly exists, and climbs to the top of Mount Sinai to find the answer.From here on in, anyone who has at least half dcent knowledge of The Bible or religious history can guess the rest of the movie (The Burning Bush, The Plagues and one of the most extraordinary moments put on film, The Parting Of The Red Sea).As I said in the first paragraph, "The Ten Commandments" is a film that couldn't be made today. In this day and age where political correctness has become the norm in Hollywood, this film could not be made without major alterations that would seriously alter the story and its message in severely negative ways in order to not anger Christian and Muslim extremist groups, who to this day are no doubt unhappy about their portrayal in the film. And of course, some nonbelieving extremist groups will naturally complain about having an explicitly religious film marketed to the mainstream moviegoing crowds. (Personally, I'm a Roman Catholic (albeit a very liberal one), a denomination of Christianity, and I have no problem with the way Christians are presented in the film or the story.)Another thing about the film is just how well the special effects hold up. This film was made at a time when you didn't have computers to aid you in the technical department. If "The Ten Commandments" was made in this day and age, everything from Moses's staff morphing into a snake to the Red Sea Parting would be done entirely in CGI. And while it would've looked quite impressive no doubt, at the same time it would be garrishly overdone and distract from the story, which is a problem with many big budget epics today. The special effects in this day are simple but effective, and aid to the story rather than overpower it. No wonder Steven Spielberg called the Red Sea Parting, "The Greatest Special Effect in Movie History".To this day, "The Ten Commandments" remains a classic among all walks of life. To enjoy this film, you don't need to be Jewish or Christian or Muslim, or even part of an organized religion. You don't even need to believe in God or a higher power. As long as you believe in the power of good over evil and doing unto others as you would do to yourself, "The Ten Commandments" will prove to be a completely satisfying motion picture experiencing.

reviewText: No doubt this `greatest motion picture of all time', as it has been called, deserves to be re-released for its 50th anniversary and at any other time too, for that matter, but this beautiful 3-disc box set has many other features to help the viewer appreciate DeMille's work and enhance viewing pleasure.  For me personally, as a silent film enthusiast, I was particularly delighted by the excellent commentary accompanying the 1923 silent film "The Ten Commandments" which deepened my understanding and appreciation of many aspects of both silent films and the making of this particular film.  It is important to note that the 1923 silent film is actually two films in one; the first 50 minutes being a condensed telling of the Biblical story of Moses, and the remaining 90 minutes is a modern-day (ie 1920s) story carrying on the same theme of why it is important to keep the ten commandments even in our day.  In itself the story is a powerful drama with many highlights, and to anyone new to silent films, no doubt Katherine Orrison's commentary will be a great help in appreciating the unique art form of the silent film, as well as DeMille's filmmaking qualities.Apart from this treat for silent film fans, the special features on disc 2 also shed more light on DeMille and his work.  A 6-part documentary covers the making of the 1956 movie in small parts only 5-10 minutes long; perhaps just the right amount to get a variety of insights, from what Cecil B DeMille was like as a person, to the monumental effort and work involved in the making of this epic film, and I personally also enjoyed Charlton Heston's comments and a few funny stories.  Another highlight for me was seeing the 10-minute 1956 "making of" segment presented by Mr DeMille himself, explaining some of the ideas behind the film.  Altogether, these special features combine to highlight once again, and to a new generation, why "The Ten Commandments" is such a celebrated motion picture and why it is timeless, having lost none of its appeal in half a century; and in fact, perhaps even gaining in appeal thanks to the commentaries and special features contained in this set.

reviewText: Cecil B. DeMille's 1956 film of THE TEN COMMANDMENTS is one of the best known films to the generation of baby boomers born after World War II. It made an icon out of Charlton Heston and the parting of the Red Sea remains one of the most spectacular and remembered of Hollywood special effects. It was the great showman's last film. It was also the second time he made a movie with that title. Ten years after coming to Hollywood in 1913 DeMille made his first version of THE TEN COMMANDMENTS which has now finally made it to DVD continuing a trend of releasing original silent films with the better known sound remakes. This is virtually the same as the VHS version that Paramount released back in 1988. It has the same Gaylord Carter organ score but is lacking the Technicolor sequence (incorrectly labeled as hand tinted) of the Exodus and parting of the Red Sea. The sequence is available unrestored as one of the DVD's special features.Unlike the 1956 blockbuster which silent film historian Robert Klepper says could just as easily have been called "The Life And Times Of Moses", the silent version uses Moses and the Egyptians as a lengthy prologue to a modern story contrasting the lives of two brothers, one who follows the Ten Commandments and one who doesn't. While the storyline is not exactly subtle in its treatment of right and wrong (one could say the same of recent Oscar winner CRASH and its treatment of racism), it is first and foremost top notch entertainment in the grand Hollywood manner with some spectacular settings (both ancient and modern) and truly remarkable special effects which are sometimes better than those used in 1956.What really makes this DVD special is the optional commentary by DeMille scholar Katherine Orrison. While I don't always agree with everything in her analysis of the film, her knowledge and especially her enthusiasm allow you to experience what it was like to view silent films in their heyday. I urge everyone who watches this film to go back and use her commentary. It really enhances the viewing experience and serves as a blueprint of how to watch silent films in general. reviewText: In the begining, deMille created a silent film. And it was good. But lo! It lacked color, it lacked sound and it lacked the great Heston. So deMile created "The Ten Commandments" anew, and saw that it was good, said that it was good, and it was... really quite corking, actually."The Ten Commandments" really only features said laws towards the end of the movie, but that's ok because as they say, getting there is half the fun. The movie is a spectacle on a grand scale, with huge sets, a cast of literally thousands, location filming in Egypt, beautiful costumes and a 1950's mentality that meant they had to sanitize quite a bit of the actual story.The tale the movie tells is one known to most people. The Hebrews are living as slaves in Egypt until God tells Moses (Charlton Heston), to go tell the Pharaoh (an amazingly good Yul Brenner), to let his people go. Moses does, Pharaoh tells him to get lost, and plagues happen. Eventually the innocent are murdered and Moses is allowed to take his people into the Promises Land where they will be slaves to God, instead of to Pharaoh.`course that's just my interpretation of Exodus.The film is specatcle of the first order, with a huge a-list of Hollywood's finest actors including Heston, Brenner, Vincent Price, Edward G Robinson, Yvone de Carlo and others. All the performances are great, particularly the two leads. Atheist though I am, even I found Heston compelling in his role as Moses.What's most interesting, though, is some of the side stories to the movie. If you pick up a copy of the DVD, you can hear an audio commentary by a woman (I forget her name, forgive me), who obviously is a believer, as was deMille. What makes that so interesting is hearing her talk about the compromises to the Biblical story that deMille made, and justifying them to herself and the audience!For example, she points out one scene where Moses is standing next to a black woman. That he had an Ethiopian wife is news to me (apparently I didn't read Exodus close enough), and this movie doesn't really want you to know that he did. All you see is a black woman standing next to Moses and some large black guy standing next to her looking more like a Zulu than an Ethiopian. In the movie there's no stammering and no Aaron talking to Pharaoh.Of course the Biblical facts had to be gussied up a little for the film, in order to make the movie more, well, movie-like. reviewText: Like most people, I watched "The Ten Commandments" on TV many times over the years while growing up. Many of its scenes are etched in my memory. But in the wake of Charlton Heston's recent death, I decided to have a marathon viewing of his films and watched "Commandments" for the first time since my adolescence. It was interesting to see it now with more mature eyes (and without being interrupted by a million commercials).Made in 1956, this film launched Heston's career as the star of big historical epics. He is dynamic and powerful as Moses, who grows up believing he is Egyptian royalty, only to discover that he is actually born of a slave. Moses becomes the messenger of God and delivers the Hebrews out of their terrible bondage. The cast is very good, especially Yul Bryner as Rameses and Sir Cedric Hardwicke as Sethi. The script is lyrical and literate, both socially conscious and reverent at the same time. The special effects in the parting of the Red Sea sequence are impressive even today, although some of the other effects (like the "pillar of fire") are animated and look pretty cheesy. However, the scene where the Angel of Death slithers through the city as a slow-moving mist is still chilling.To modern audiences, the film will seem melodramatic and exaggerated, but that was the intended style. The director, Cecil B. DeMille, got his start making silent movies where the actors needed to overact to convey the emotion of the scene. In fact, the 50th anniversary DVD of "Commandments" includes the 1923 version, also directed by DeMille. In the earlier film, the story of Moses and Rameses is featured only in the prologue, which is then followed by a "modern day" story of two brothers and what happens if a person does not live by God's laws. It's a wonderful time capsule of movie making and it's interesting to compare (and contrast) it to the later film. Despite it's age, the silent version has surprisingly good special effects.The other extras in the 50th Anniversary set are also good. There is a 40-minute documentary on the making of the film which features interviews with surviving cast members, including Heston. There are also enthusiastic and informative commentaries by Katherine Orrison on both versions of the film. She shares many interesting anecdotes and behind-the-scenes stories, and both are worth a listen.So if you've never seen "The Ten Commandments," by all means you should. If it's been a while, revisit the grandeur and spectacle of this cinema classic.

reviewText: I just recently viewed this film again, and it's fantastic.  Sure, it's a little simplistic at times and has "great" dialogue (oh, you adorable fool, Moses), but at the same time, it has brilliant cinemtography, great performances (say what you will, but Heston is very good here, as is Brynner, Hardwicke, and even Baxter).  It has a deep sincerity that most modern films lack.  DeMille is totally within his element here, with massive crowd scenes (which he was a master at), great epic storytelling (the film is never boring despite its nearly 4 hour length), and there's a dignity and sincerity to this film that so many modern films lack.  DeMille was 76 at the time he made this, and he even had a heart attack on the set, but that did not preclude him from finishing this masterpiece.  There was no CGI back in these days, so everyone extra you see is a real person, and some of the special effecdts are still quite startling.  The rich, Vistavision, Technicolor cinemtography is wonderful to behold, with a great sense of composition.  There's not much cutting in this film either.  DeMille lets his shots run a bit on the lengthy side (he's no Tarkovsky or Tarr, whose shot lengths reach nearly 10 minutes at times), but the lack of cutting gives the film a rich pace, similar to that of a lengthy novel.  It's a wonderful picture.With this 50th anniversary edition, you get to see DeMille's 1923 version of this same story.  The 1956 version is better of course, but the 1956 version is about the commandments and the plight of the Hebrew slaves.  The 1923 version has a 45 minute prologue about the commandments, then goes into a modern parable about 2 brothers, one sinner and one saint.  I'm really writing about the '56 version, which I adore.  The '23 version is worth seeing at least once, but doesn't really compare to the more (rightfully so) famous version.  The 1923 is still fascinating to watch, though, especially from a historical perspective.  This is a great example of classic Hollywood.  The 2 films made seem hokey and corny at times (they are a bit), but it was a different time, and the films (at least for me) still speak volumes.
summary: A great epic, DeMille's last film, and a superb way to close out a great career...

reviewerName: Jacques COULARDEAU "A soul doctor, so to say"
reviewText: You have to be nostalgic to go back to such a long and typical film of 1956. And yet the film has kept an intense charm. The special effects are of course old but they are believable: you cannot see the zipper in the back of the monstrous pharaoh. The charm though does not come from that brilliant set, the great costumes, the perfect acting, for this distant period at least. The actors speak the way actors used to speak on a sound stage because it was filmed on a sound stage. So the language is unnatural, artificial, over-dramatic, staged in one word. The charm comes from the story itself. You do not need to believe in it to appreciate it. It is a beautiful and magical story of love and struggle, of slavery and freedom. That is this very human charm that still attracts us. Those who believe in the divine nature of the story are just adding something else to it but they are not changing this story: a humane and deeply emotional story about a few human beings who are suddenly confronted with a fundamental choice: do I help myself and remain happy in my corner or do I help those I consider as my people to get free and happy in their turn? That's the choice of Moses and he goes the right way. But in 1956, when McCarthyism and the vast repression against the Communists were raging, before Rosa Parks refused to stand up and yield her seat to a white passenger on a bus, Hollywood had found a way to remain on the side of those who suffered. They produced films like this one that was punctuated all along by this simple sentence that had accompanied and would accompany the long struggle for civil rights: Let my people go. That is in no way Christian or Buddhist, Moslem or Hindu. It is just human and eternal because there will always be some freedom to conquer for everyone or just for one group of people. Freedom is not natural: it is a human creation and invention.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU, University Paris 1 Pantheon Sorbonne, University Paris 12 Créteil, CEGID

reviewText: For many people Cecil B. DeMille's 1956 remake of his own THE TEN COMMANDMENTS is so iconic it practically defines the Hollywood movie as much as any picture (with the possible exception of GONE WITH THE WIND). Even more than fifty years later it's capable of giving tremendous pleasure despite its incredible length (three hours and thirty-nine minutes) and its style which was extremely anachronistic even for the time. DeMille, who had forever made his name as one of the most important and powerful directors of the silent era, directs his actors as if they still were in the silents, so their gestures and poses are big and their emotions even bigger. Probably the most fun for contemporary audiences is Anne Baxter as the Throne Princess Nefretiri, who gets to deliver all kinds of howlers to Charlton Heston as Moses ("You will be king of Egypt and I will be your footstool!"), but pretty much everyone involved seems to be having a grand old time. Particularly fun are Yul Brynner as a haughty Pharaoh Ramses, Nina Foch as the kindly Princess Bithia, Edward G. Robinson in his bizarre role as Dathan the evil Hebrew governor, and Sir Cedric Hardwicke as the old pharaoh Seti.And then there's the spectacle, which every DeMille movie promises and on which he did not skimp in this film. One of DeMille's specialties was the presentation of the more salacious aspects of sinfulness, and so we have no less than two extended sequences with dancing girls, not to mention Baxter's diaphanous gowns and Brynner and Heston and John Derek (as a Douglas Fairbanks-like Joshua) wearing practically nothing on their chests for large periods of the film. There's also the killing of the firstborn of Egypt, the staining of the Nile, and pillar of fire, the Golden Calf and a very impressive parting of the Red Sea (the most famous of the film's sequences). Heston seems stranger and stranger as the film progresses, with even wilder wigs, but all this seems in keeping with the entire tone of the thing. Even when you laugh at it you can't help but be impressed.This fiftieth-anniversary edition adds DeMille's long missing introduction to his own film plus long musical sequences for the overture and the entr'acte; it also comes with his original 1923 version (which is extremely different, with sections set in the contemporary period for the time much like Griffith's INTOLERANCE).

reviewText: I confess, I'm a "Ten Commandments" fanatic.  The 1956 film is my favorite movie of all time, and I think I own every video release ever sold.  I bought the 50th Anniversary Collection, however, only to have DeMille's 1923 "Ten Commandments," which I wanted to see for curiosity's sake.  I was really surprised by the 1923 "Ten Commandments" -- same title, VASTLY different story!  (Anyone who says that the 1956 movie is a remake of his 1923 silent film is way off the mark here.)The 1923 version does begin with a relatively brief telling of how Moses led the Children of Israel out of bondage from Egypt and receives the Ten Commandments, but the lion's share of the movie deals with the two McTavish brothers and their elderly, God-fearing mother.  The older brother, John, holds true to his mother's teachings from the Bible, but the younger brother, Dan, swears he's going to break every one of the Ten Commandments, and become rich and powerful in the process.  And somewhere in the mix is Mary, a beautiful girl, down on her luck, who is taken in by the McTavishes after she steals food from Dan at a diner.  Hard-working, responsible John falls in love with Mary, but it's the rakish Dan who steals her heart and wisks her away.  They marry, and Dan becomes a successful (and unscrupulous) building contractor.  John keeps working away as an honest carpenter, and takes care of their mother.  Dan finds, however, that one cannot mock God forever and get away with it, and the life and fortune he built breaking each and every commandment comes crashing down around his ears.  It's a pretty predictable morality play, but I was still hooked, waiting to see how things would turn out for the two brothers and the woman they both love.There are some (I assume unintentionally) funny moments in the Moses story, which is called the "prologue" of the 1923 film.  When Ramses dismisses Moses without releasing the Israelites before the tenth plague, Moses gives a shrug that seems to say "Oh, well -- I tried!"  And it's too, too easy to improvise humorous dialogue for Moses, Miriam, Aaron, "Dathan the Discontented," Ramses, etc. as the vignettes play out in the over-the-top acting style of the silent film era.(For those missing the hand-tinted footage of Moses in the desert -- look in the special features section of the third disk.  It's there.)Since the 50th Anniversary Collection is, by and large, identical to the 2004 Special Collector's Edition, I wasn't originally planning to buy it.  My curiosity about the 1923 film finally got the better of me, however, and I am glad I've seen it.

reviewText: This movie influenced my childhood more than any other film---save, perhaps Gone With The Wind. Yes, it was pure ham. Yes, the story is ridiculous and over-the-top. Yes, a lot of the acting is bad. Yes, nowadays I can barely make it 20 minutes into the movie before I yawn and turn to something else. Oh, but as a 6 year-old child! It was pure magic, glorious and inspiring. Probably in all the wrong ways, of course. What I took from this fabulous spectacle as a child: it inspired my fascination with Ancient Egypt; I fell in love with Anne Baxter (maybe she was over-acting, but she oozed glamour and sensuality!), and it led me to find more, and much better films of hers, like Orson Wells' The Magnificent Ambersons; Yul Bryner exuded masculinity; he defined my image of a Pharoh (minus his butt-kicking by Moses). I could never understand what Nefretiri saw in Charlton Heston's boring old Moses, when she had bad-boy Bryner beside her the whole time! Which brings me to my point: as a Biblical lesson, De Mille's Ten Commandments is an utter failure. I always sympathized with the grand, gorgeously costumed Egyptians. To me (as a child) Moses was the villian for messing everything up. Why would anyone want to follow a ragged old Moses, always ranting and raving like a madman, into the ugly desert when Egypt looked so rich and wonderful. It never made sense why a powerful prince would want to trade all that treasure for rags and sand. It was the beginning of a trend I noticed in nearly all Biblical films from that era: the doomed pagans always seemed more attractive than the supposed good guys. The bad guys were having all the fun! Historically, of course, this film is utter hogwash...but I'll save those details for another time. It was great viewing as a child, and for those memories, I give it four stars.

reviewText: Cecil B. DeMille was a motion-picture producer-director whose use of spectacle attracted vast audiences and made him a dominant figure in Hollywood... He was successful in a genre - the epic - that he made definitely his own, until William Wyler came along three years later with "Ben Hur."In his first epic role, Charlton Heston is cast as Lord Moses, prince of Egypt, son of the pharaoh's sister...As a true prince, he saves a slave's life; as a great prince, he gives the priest's grain to the slaves and one day in seven to rest; as a man of justice, he confronts Nefretiri with a piece of Hebrew cloth, the key to his origin; as a warrior and in excellent physical condition, he kills a tough and cruel master builder; as a courageous Hebrew, son of slaves, he tells the pharaoh: "It would take more than a man to lead the slaves from bondage, but if I could free them, I would!" As a man of prowess, he shows his latest methods of combat when he takes on the shepherds and routed them; as God's torch, he proves to be the Deliverer of the Hebrews, their prophet and leader; as the Lawgiver of the Covenant, he is the founder of the community; and as interpreter of "The Ten Commandments," he is an organizer and legislator...Yul Brynner is superb as Rameses, the rival of Moses... His arrogance and swaggering snobbery are well represented... Brynner delivers an intelligent cynical role... Regarding himself as divine, he rejects the demand of this unknown God and responds by increasing the oppression of the Hebrews...Anne Baxter is Nefretiri, the sensual princess who leaves her scar upon Moses' heart... Nefretiri is beautiful as a jewel, and her eyes green as the Cedars of Lebanon... For Moses, she is always ready to lie, to kill and betray... She is selfish in her life as certainly in her love...Edward G. Robinson plays Dathan, the chief Hebrew overseer who confessed to Rameses: "Give me my freedom and I'll give you the scepter. Give me the water girl Lilia and I'll give you the princess your heart's desire." As a treacherous overlord, he charges to the people yelling: "Go where? To drown in the sea?"Yvonne De Carlo plays Sephora, the midnight shepherdess to whom Moses is wed... Sephora couldn't fill the emptiness of Moses' heart, but promised not to be jealous of the memory...John Derek is Joshua, the stone cutter, who is totally convinced that Moses is God's Messenger...Debra Paget plays the delicate flower who quench the thirst of the working slaves... For her the hour of deliverance will never come...Sir Cedric Hardwicke plays Sethi, the mighty Pharaoh, whose words to his son mark great significance: "Who would take a throne by force that he has earned by deeds?"Nina Foch plays Bithiah, pharaoh's sister, who discovers the basket in which Moses has just floated down the Nile...Vincent Price plays Baka the sadistic, covetous, murderous whip-wielding slave-driver..."The Ten Commandments" is filled with tremendous special effects: Moses's staff turns to a snake; Moses turning the Nile to blood; the Passover of the Angel of Death striking all the Egyptian first-born; the tremendous pillar of fire which halts Rameses' men; the Exodus from Egypt; the parting of the Red Sea; and the delivery of the "Laws of life, and right, and good, and evil."The relationship between God and man is the powerful drama in our world... Moses is 'every man,' in his pride and humility, in his courage and prowess, in his love and hatred, in his weakness and confusion,in his conduct and ability...DeMille's "The Ten Commandments" is a moving story of the spirit of freedom rising in a man under the divine inspiration of his Maker... It is a remarkable spectacle with great music, filled with exceptional setting and decor...

reviewText: Cecil  B. DeMille's THE TEN COMMANDMENTS (1956, Paramount) may be the greatest Biblical epic in Hollywood's history.  People tend to ridicule it, but generally without seeing it.  Yes, it has corny dialogue at times, but a glance at the long 1956 theatrical trailer with DeMille in his office, surrounded by Bibles and other religious items, leaves no doubt that this is an old-fashioned showman and devoutly religious man.  He was born in the 1880's and came of age during a time of traveling carnival shows with theatrical dialogue and larger-than-life performances.  So when it came time to do a wide-screen. color, sound remake of his own excellent 1923 silent epic, he would remember the carnival epics of his youth.  We believe the message and manner of speaking in the 1956 film because DeMille believed in it sincerely.  He wanted us to, quite simply, live according to The Ten Commandments because God wanted that.Nominated for seven  Oscars, including Best Picture (it lost to Mike Todd's AROUND THE WORLD IN 80 DAYS), THE TEN COMMANDMENTS tells the life of Moses (Charlton Heston) from infancy to old age in ancient Egypt.  Though secretly Hebrew, he  lives the life of a pharaoh.  The supporting cast is very impressive-Yul Brynner as Rameses, Anne Baxter as Nefretiri, Edward G. Robinson as Dathan, lovely Debra Paget as Lilia and John Derek as Joshua (their career performances), Martha Scott and Yvonne DeCarlo, evil Vincent Price, and literally a cast of thousands during the Exodus climax.  DeMille had many technical advisors and believed "the film was made in the office", meaning when the screenplay was completely finished line for line and scene for scene.  He prided himself on having every single extra know exactly who they were playing and what they were doing story-wise.  Maybe that it one  reason his movies hold up so well.  The Oscar-nominated color cinematography, art direction, and costume design are gorgeously colorful, but faithful to the period.  Best of all is the greatest music score Elmer Bernstein ever composed, thunderous and wonderful.  And inexplicably not an Oscar nominee; nor was DeMille as Director, go figure.The 50th anniversary DVD includes a DeMille introduction and full fifteen minutes of Bernstein roadshow bookend music not in the TV print.  It also includes a very informative and insightful audio commentary by DeMille scholar and author Katherine Orrison that will let you know Mr. DeMille was dead serious in his film intentions here.  Watch this 1956 epic after hearing criticism about how hokey it is, and you may be floored by how engrossing and literate it is.  It moves and is beautifully paced by editor Anne Bauchens for four full hours (including the roadshow music).  There is also a six-part documentary on the making of the movie behind the scenes.If you need more of an excuse to buy this new and downright cheap (only $15.50 from Amazon.com) DVD set that sprawls across three disks in an exquisite box, Paramount Home Video has included the 136 minute 1923 silent version by Mr. DeMille as a kind of double feature.  It is very impressive in its own right.  And the fact that the filmmaker believed in his story about living according to The Ten Commandments may be why we believe in his story also eight decades later.  DeMille gives us a 45 minute Biblical prologue, basically the last  45 minutes of the remake-the Exodus out of Egypt, the parting of the Red Sea, and the creation of the Ten Commandments from God to Moses on Mount Sinai.  His sets are truly gigantic, but the human story and character details down to the bit roles are never lost.The remaining 90 minutes of the silent version are a Modern Story set (and filmed) in 1923 San Francisco.  We have good (Richard Dix) and bad (Rod La Rocque) brothers, a mother (Edythe Chapman) who lives every word of the Bible, and a likeable leading lady (Leatrice Joy).  In essence, good brother lives according to the Bible and loves mom, while bad brother and his mistress take a path to Hell disobeying God's teachings.  He is an architect, and trust me when I say you do not want to lease or buy one of his buildings!  What makes this silent original so great, aside from a thrilling Wurlitzer pipe organ score by the great Gaylord Carter, is that the good brother is not all goody-good and the bad brother is not all evil. reviewText: Life is full of spice when there is drama involved. This world would have been such a boring place if Lucifer had not rebelled. Drama fills up the blanks in life where the balance of good and evil aligns to make this universe interesting. So is the case with a good play or a film. All the ingredients that make this the greatest film of all times are painted into this canvas by the master painter, Cecil.B.DeMille. This was his last work and in 1956 he gave the world a film carved out of not so well known passages on the life and times of Moses and the deliverance of the Ten Commandments. There are scenes in the film that remain with you till eternity. The opening shot of the innumerable Jewish slaves working on the busts, columns and pillars during Pharaoh Sethi's regime with a dark red painted on the big Cinevista 65 lens making you gasp at such an early stage. The editing is superb. Each scene fills its part. When Moses is driven out and spends forty days in the wilderness of Sinai, the photography is awesome. The red and orange flames on the Mount Sinai when Moses first encounters the mountain are superb. The burning bush is craftsmanship at its best without the techno supports of the modern age. the scenes of the plagues in Egypt with the Nile turning red and culminating with the descent of the hand of death on the Passover day from the dark blue night sky and clouds are without a parallel even after 52 years. What do you say then about the parting of the Red Sea? This has to be the greatest scene filmed ever and without computer graphics, too. My God! Finally the scenes of the Ten Commandments being written on stone with fire and lightning from the sky ("written with the fingers of God Himself"!) on Mount Sinai together with the abrupt arrival of Moses during the lascivious revelry under the mount leave you breathless. Charlton Heston as Moses is absolutely divine and you just can't say that he is not Moses there. Yul Brynner is Ramases II in the flesh. I don't think anyone else would have carried out that role as he did. Sir Cedric Hardwicke is superb as Sethi. Anne Baxter as Nefretiri is gorgeous. She enjoys the role to the hilt. A lovely cameo by Vincent Price as Baka the Master Builder. Edward.G.Robinson is excellent as Dathan the overseer. John Derek is effective as Joshua. Debra Paget as the water girl Lilia is admirable. The entire film's drama is bound and woven into a fine texture by Elmer Bernstein with his superb symphonic score. The regal theme of Moses and deliverance remains fresh in my mind even today. Drama doesn't get bigger than this.There are films being made after this; tons of them; yet, this remains the film to beat with William Wyler's Ben Hur coming real close.

reviewText: I walked into Blockbuster with a Coupon the kids gave me for Christmas the day this film was to be shown on ABC TV. Having just gotten a 720P DLP Projector and a new Sound Amp, I thought I'd give this disc the side by side treatment. I'm also a projectionist in a theatre were we showed Ten Commandments a few years ago. A Man walked up to me in the theatre and asked me why I was showing the print in Scope. I told him that was the way it was sent to us. He was appalled. I asked him why he was so interested. "I'm the guy who restored the sound. I drove all the way down from New Jersey to see this print." So I bought the disc, and that night I cranked up the 7ft wide screen with surround and was surprised to see ABC broadcasting a smudgy looking 1.33 version of the film on their HD Channels!!!! This DVD looked much better than the broadcast, plus it included the missing visual information. The film was shot in Vista Vision. IMDB Says 1.85 ratio, but I think Vista Vision was 1.66-1.75? Certainly not scope or 1.33. So the version we had at our theatre was cropped on the top and bottom to look like Cinemascope, and the version on ABC this year was cropped on the sides to look like 1.33. The DVD looks right. For instance, in the scene where Mosses is brought to Pharaoh in chains, on ABC it was just Pharaoh and Mosses in the shot, on the DVD there are two extra people on each side of them. The DVD looked a bit sharper too, and of course you would have expected the ABC HD broadcast to look better. I suspect ABC just threw on the old tape they've been using year after year and they haven't bothered to remaster it for HD broadcast yet. And then they wonder why people are drifting away from Broadcast TV by the big networks? So over all, in spite of some reviews I've seen here, I didn't think this disc looked that bad. I enjoyed the heck out of it on my big screen. I'd like to see a few more extras when they get around to releasing this on Blue Ray, but for now this version will do nicely. I was also very glad to get the 1923 Silent version! That also looks pretty good to me.

reviewText: This DVD is a true collectors delight - not only is Cecil B. De Mille's last great epic presented in its original widescreen format alongside De Mille's original and very different silent version, but alongside an impressive new documentary, the legendary ten-minute trailer has been included for good measure.Sitting in his office, with the aid of a wicker basket, a Van Dyke portrait, two stone tablets and a Bible he occasionally bashes, De  Mille pitches "the greatest adventure story ever put between the covers of a book!" He solemnly assures us that Heston was cast for his resemblance to Michelangelo's statue of Moses and to prove it, he even shows us a photograph of the actor standing next to it (they look nothing alike!). One of McCarthy's staunchest Hollywood allies in the fifties anti-communist witch-hunts, he goes on to draw none-too-subtle comparisons between the tyranny of Pharaoh and the un-named forces of dictatorship that threaten us 'even to this very day', then promptly switches to plugging the sex and spectacle with the kind of wanton abandon that only the highest-minded puritans can muster; "Moses is one of the world's greatest human beings - and human he was to the point of SIN! And holy to the point of seeing God." Ever the showman, he even pops out from behind the curtains just before the film itself starts to give us the same spiel in case we missed the point and inform us that "The picture runs three hours and thirty-nine minutes; there will be an intermission."After such a relentless barrage of hyperbole, disappointment would seem inevitable, but unlike most of De Mille's films, The Ten Commandments stands up remarkably well. Filling in the gaps in the Bible's version of events with lust, treachery and other soap opera staples, it is the complete antithesis of the `think man's epics' that followed in the Sixties. The dialogue is declamatory, the style overtly theatrical, often recoursing to striking tableaux reminiscent of the Biblical pageants of Victorian era. The performances are painted in broad strokes, with Anne Baxter emoting something rotten and Heston, his hair getting whiter every time he has a chin-wag with God, a square-jawed and solemn All-American Deliverer.  Even John P. Fulton's Oscar-winning special effects show their age as well as their matte lines. It would be almost absurdly easy to tear it to pieces were it not for the fact that De Mille's implicit belief in what he put on the screen enables him to carry it off with considerable panache. This is an audience picture on a grand scale, and great fun too.The colour is almost as superb as the original VistaVision Technicolor, the print perfect apart from some slight occasional negative damage in the top right-hand corner of the frame. More hokum than holy it may be, but with a terrific cast and, even now, a genuine sense of wonder to its set-pieces, The Ten Commandments delivers nearly four hours of great entertainment. And the parting of the Red Sea is still one of the great movie moments, matte lines or not. Enjoy!
summary: "The greatest adventure story ever put between the covers of a book!"
